review.title: Regularized Spectral Clustering under the Degree-Corrected Stochastic Blockmodel
review.abstract: Spectral clustering is a fast and popular algorithm for finding clusters in networks. Recently, Chaudhuri et al. (2012) and Amini et al.(2012) proposed inspired variations on the algorithm that artificially inflate the node degrees for improved statistical performance. The current paper extends the previous statistical estimation results to the more canonical spectral clustering algorithm in a way that removes any assumption on the minimum degree and provides guidance on the choice of the tuning parameter. Moreover, our results show how the "star shape" in the eigenvectors--a common feature of empirical networks--can be explained by the Degree-Corrected Stochastic Blockmodel and the Extended Planted Partition model, two statistical models that allow for highly heterogeneous degrees. Throughout, the paper characterizes and justifies several of the variations of the spectral clustering algorithm in terms of these models.

sections.heading: 5. Simulation and Analysis of Political Blogs
sections.text: This chapter compares five different methods of spectral clustering with high values. Experiment 1 generates networks from the DC-SBM with other methods. Experiment 2 generates networks from the standard SBM. Finally, the benefits of regulation are presented in an empirical network from the political blogosphere during the 2004 presidential elections (Adamic and Glance [17]). The simulations compare (1) standard spectral clustering (SC), (2) RSC as defined in Section 2, (3) RSC without projecting to the unit Sphere (RSC wp), (4) regulates SC with thresholds (t-RSC), and (5) spectral clustering with perturbation (SCP) (Amini et al), which SC applies to the perturbed adjacency matrix Aper = A + a11T. Furthermore, Experiment 2 compares the performance of RSC with high values.

sections.heading: 6. Discussion
sections.text: Our theoretical results supplement the current results by examining the regulatory step in a more canonical version of the spectral cluster algorithm. Furthermore, our main results do not require assumptions about the minimum degree of the node. This is crucial because it allows us to investigate situations where multiple nodes have low leverage; regulation is most advantageous in these situations. Finally, our results show that the choice of a tuning parameter close to the average creates a balance between several competing objectives. Thanks to Sara Fernandes-Taylor for helpful comments.
